Ameren, formed in 1997, is a public utility holding company whose primary assets are its equity interests in its subsidiaries . Dividends on Ameren’s common stock and the payment of expenses by Ameren depend on distributions made to it by its subsidiary . Ameren also has other subsidiaries that conduct other activities, such as providing shared services .
 The rates that Ameren Missouri, Ameren Illinois, and ATXI are allowed to charge for their utility services significantly influence the results of operations, financial position, and liquidity of these companies and Ameren . The electric and natural gas utility industry is highly regulated . The utility rates charged to customers are determined by governmental entities, including the MoPSC, the ICC, and the FERC .
 The extent of the regulatory lag varies for each of Ameren’s electric and natural gas jurisdictions . The effects of regulatory lag are mitigated by various means, including annual revenue requirement reconciliations, the decoupling of revenues from sales volumes to ensure revenues approved in a regulatory rate review are not affected by changes in sales volumes .
 Ameren Missouri’s electric generation, transmission, and delivery service rates are bundled together and charged to retail customers under a combined electric service rate . Rate changes consistent with the December 2024 order became effective in late December 2024 . Ameren Illinois will reconcile its actual revenue requirement, as adjusted for certain cost variations, to ICC-approved electric distribution rates .
 The 10.48% return includes a 50-basis-point incentive adder for participation in an RTO . Ameren Missouri, Ameren Illinois, and ATXI must receive FERC approval to enter into various transactions, such as issuing short-term debt securities and conducting certain acquisitions, mergers, and consolidations .
 Ameren Missouri, Ameren Illinois, and ATXI are members of the SERC . The SERC represents all or portions of 16 central and southeastern states under authority from the NERC . If any of the three companies fail to comply with reliability standards approved by the FERC, they could face sanctions .
 Ameren Missouri’s Keokuk Energy Center is operated under authority granted by an Act of Congress in 1905 . Federal and state authorities periodically review and modify existing regulations and adopt new regulations . Recent and potential new executive orders issued by the current federal administration as well as local and state land use requirements can also impact our planning activities .
 Ameren owns an integrated transmission system that is composed of the transmission assets of Ameren Missouri, Ameren Illinois, and ATXI . The Ameren transmission system directly connects with 15 other balancing authority areas for the exchange of electric energy . Ameren sells all of its capacity to the MISO and purchases the capacity it needs to supply its native load sales .
 In 2022, the FERC issued an order approving changes to the annual MISO capacity auction . Historically, the auctions were designed to cover annual peak demand plus a target reserve margin . The seasonal auction structure was established to help to address variability in resources as the MISO begins to rely more heavily on renewable generation . Ameren Missouri files a long-term nonbinding preferred resource plan with the MoPSC every three years .
 Ameren Missouri continues to evaluate its longer-term needs for new generating capacity . The addition of renewable, natural gas-fired, or nuclear generation facilities is subject to obtaining necessary project approvals . The need for investment in new sources of energy is dependent on several key factors, including factors such as customer energy-efficiency and demand response programs .
 Ameren Missouri continues to study alternatives and take steps to preserve options to meet future demand . Changes in U.S. energy policy and priorities under the current federal administration could lead to retirement of current baseload assets before the end of their current useful lives or alterations in the way those assets operate, which could result in increased capital expenditures and increased operations and maintenance expenses .
 In 2024, 2023, and 2022, Ameren Illinois procured power on behalf of its customers for 25%, 28%, and 28%, respectively, of its total kilowatthour sales . Customers that elect to enroll in net metering are allowed to net their generation against their distribution usage within each billing month .
 Ameren Illinois is required to file a Grid Plan with the ICC every four years . The Grid Plan outlines how Ameren . Illinois expects to invest in electric distribution infrastructure in order to support grid modernization, clean energy, energy efficiency, and the state of Illinois’ renewable energy, equity, climate, . climate, electrification, and environmental .
 Both of Ameren Missouri’s coal-fired energy centers were constructed prior to 1978 . The Callaway Energy Center began operation in 1984 and is licensed to operate until 2044 . Ameren Illinois operates two solar generation facilities . The third solar generation facility is planned to be placed in service before the end of 2026 .
